thread.title: Youths fast break toward the future in recruiting showcase
thread.title_full: Youths fast break toward the future in recruiting showcase - Sun Sentinel

author: Gary Curreri
title: Youths fast break toward the future in recruiting showcase
text:
In the recent Comin' For That #1 Spot Basketball Showcase in Coral Springs, the adage that "it doesn't matter whether you win or lose, it's how you play the game" was certainly appropriate.
The two-day, 10th annual tournament at the Coral Springs Gymnasium featured more than 200 boys and girls from area middle and high schools showcasing their skills for college coaches and recruiters.
Part of the action was Sunrise's Michael King II, 13, an eighth-grader at Westpine Middle School who is regarded as one of the top eighth-graders in his class by several scouting services.
"I feel no pressure because I feel like I belong," said King, who was performing in his first showcase. "It's awesome. It is a good experience. I just play my game and pay attention to the court. This is very important to me."
King was placed on a team by the luck of the draw.
"It's not that difficult because all of us play basketball," he said. "You just move the ball and play. Luckily, I play with guys who are not selfish, and they move the ball. It is my dream to play in the NBA, so I am willing to do whatever it takes."
Pembroke Pines resident Immanuel West, 16, plays at Miami Norland High School, where he is a sophomore. This was his second showcase event in the past year, but his first time playing using a random selection process.
"This was important to me to see how I play with all different players under a different [system]," West said. "This helps me get my skills better and develop different ways of playing. It gives me more experience about training and what college coaches are going to be looking for in the future."
Dudley Blackwell, a 13-year-old from Miramar, was also playing in his second showcase event. The Sagemont School eighth-grader said wanted to show people he has what it takes to get to the next level.
"I get to show my talents," Blackwell said. "Pressure is not in my vocabulary. I try not to look at them or think about it. I just play my game like there is nobody here, like it is an open gym."
Deerfield Beach's Herman Robinson, 17, showed he could run the floor and hit long-range jumpers.
"This is pretty big to come out here and show my skills and be put on the map," said Robinson, a junior at Highlands Christian Academy. "There have been a lot of good players that have come through here. It's a great program."
Tournament organizer Tony Perkins said there were athletes from around the state, including as far away as Jacksonville. The boys played on Saturday, the girls on Sunday.
"The purpose is to get a lot of these kids in South Florida exposure on a national level," Perkins said. "We want to help them get seen and recognized by some of the larger scouting services in the United States."
The athletes pay $125 to play in the event, and each participant is guaranteed three games.
"They come and we give them skill development training in the morning, which a lot of these events don't provide," Perkins said. "The biggest thing we try to do is provide coaching and exposure. They also get competitive games. We mix them up on different teams, and some of the coaches from the local high schools and travel teams [are involved]."
Many players, including Sagemont School graduate Prince Ali (UCLA), have played in the showcase and gone on to college.
"What we pride ourselves in is identifying the kids early and monitoring them through their high school careers," Perkins said. "It gives us a chance to identify them when they are as young as in the sixth grade."
